## BES

<img src="dummyBES.png" style="height: 100%; width: 100%; object-fit: contain" onclick="window.open('https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07278', 'blank');"/>

(dummy text from ChatGPT) Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (BES) encompass the variety of life on Earth (biodiversity) and the benefits that ecosystems provide to humanity (ecosystem services). These services include provisioning services like food and water; regulating services that affect climate, floods, and disease; supporting services such as soil formation and nutrient cycling; and cultural services like recreational, spiritual, and cultural benefits. BES are crucial for human well-being, as they contribute to health, livelihoods, and enjoyment of life. The preservation of biodiversity is fundamental for maintaining the balance and resilience of ecosystems, which in turn ensures the continued provision of vital services that support societal economic and social development, health, and quality of life.

## LULC

<img src="dummyLULC.png" style="height: 100%; width: 100%; object-fit: contain" onclick="window.open('https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.08866', 'blank');"/>

(dummy text from ChatGPT) Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) refers to the physical and biological cover over the earth's surface, including water, vegetation, bare soil, and artificial structures, influenced by human activities and natural processes. The way land is used and covered can significantly influence biodiversity and ecosystems, as well as the services they provide, such as air and water purification, climate regulation, and soil fertility. Changes in LULC can lead to habitat loss, fragmentation, and degradation, negatively impacting biodiversity by reducing the number of species and altering ecosystem functions. Conversely, sustainable land use practices can support biodiversity conservation and enhance the resilience and productivity of ecosystems, thus maintaining and improving the services they provide to humans.
